newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria domestic debt rises 26 pct in November.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria domestic debt rises 26 pct in November.

text.p: Bulgaria's domestic debt rose by 171 billion levs to 839.3 billion levs in November because of a fall in the lev and new government securities issues placed to bridge the budget gap, Finance Ministry figures showed.
Some 114 billion levs of the rise were due to the lev decline, which boosted the price of dollar-denominated bad loan bonds and deposit guarantee bonds, figures showed.
Ten new treasury paper issues were sold to financial institutions last month to finance the central government budget deficit, boosting domestic debt by some 62.5 billion levs.
The lev fell to 354 per dollar on November 30 from 242 on November 1 in the central bank daily dollar fix used in the calculations.

The Finance Ministry has issued $79 million worth of floater coupon T-bonds this year so far to cover foreign currency deposits of companies and individuals in five of the 13 banks, against which the central bank has filed insolvency suits.
Bad debt bonds worth 32 billion levs and $1.8 billion respectively were issued two years ago to cover banks' non-performing loans extended to state companies before 1991. @
The Finance Ministry said recently it planned to meet most maturity and coupon payments on treasury papers by rollover issues of government securities to bridge the budget gap.
The central government budget deficit topped the annual target by 92.5 percent in November, rising to 155.4 billion levs.
The parliament tentatively approved on Friday a budget revision including a 115 billion lev loan to the government to cover domestic debt payments, despite the central bank's opposition.

The revision, this year's second, was sought by the government after it overshot the macroeconomic targets in the July revision. The bill will have a second reading this week. -- Anastas Petrov, Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-876032
